name: Abyssal Grenadier
text: The Grenadier, also called Rattail, is among the deepest common benthic fish of the deep and has been recorded as deep as 7000m (22.970 ft).

name: Abyssal Sea Cucumber
text: What is yellow, 40 cm long, has 7 lips, 92 feet and a spikey head like a punk? An abyssal sea cucumber of course!

name: Abyssal Spiderfish
text: The abyssal spiderfish is a simultaneous hermaphrodite, meaning it has both male and female sex organs at the same time, which also makes self-fertilization possible.

name: Anglerfish
text: The male anglerfish has one goal – to find a female, bite into her flesh and become fused to her body.  After losing his own organs, the male becomes a sexual parasite, providing sperm for the female.

name: Armored Searobin
text: These fish have evolved 6 crab-like legs to walk on the seafloor.

name: Barreleye Fish
text: The barreleye fish can track prey with its extremely light-sensitive rotating eyes.

name: Basking Shark
text: Despite being longer than a double-decker bus and the second largest fish in the world, this gentle giant only feeds on tiny plancton.

name: Big Red Jelly
text: The big red jelly uses 4-7 fleshy "feeding arms" instead of stinging tentecles to capture food.

name: Bigfin Squid
text: Scientists think it's likely this fascinating species of squid uses its long arms and tentacles to trap prey thats bumps into them as they hang down in the water.

name: Black Swallower
text: This deep-sea fish can swallow prey 2 times its size and up to 10 times its own body mass.

name: Blobfish
text: Against common belief the "world's ugliest animal" isn't actually that ugly in its natural habitat. Its jellylike body is perfectly adapted to life under pressure and loses its shape when brought up to the surface.

name: Bloodybelly Comb Jelly
text: The comb jelly's apparent shimmering is due to their so-callled cilia (little appendages for locomotion) that are diffracting light as they move.

name: Coelacanth
text: Often times called a "living fossil" the coelacanth was thought to have gone extinct 66 million years ago before it was discovered alive and well in 1938.

name: Coffinfish
text: Coffinfish have developed special features to survive the deep sea: they can walk on their fins and have evolved enormous gills so they can hold their breath for up to 4 minutes.

name: Crown Jelly
text: One of the most common deep-sea jellyfish, its bright red color keeps the crown jelly hidden - red is one of the first colors to disappear when light becomes scarce in the depths.

name: Cusk Eel
text: Despite their name, cusk eels aren't actually eels, but bony fish. They get the name from their long body and eel-like appearance.

name: Cuviers Beaked Whale
text: This deep-sea dwelling whale can reach depths of almost 3.000m when hunting for squid and other prey.

name: Dumbo Octopus
text: Dumbo octopus is a genus of octopus containing the deepest living octopus species, their name originating from their resemblance to the Disney character "Dumbo" because of their floppy, ear-like fins.

name: Dwarf Lantern Shark
text: Reaching only 20 cm at most, the dwarf lantern shark is the smallest shark species and fits into a human hand.

name: Elephant Seal
text: Elephant seals are remarkable divers, spending up tp 1.5 hours underwater and reaching depths of more than 1700m while searching for food.

name: Faceless Fish
text: Also called faceless cusk, this fish is named after its extremely reduced "face" -  it does not have visible eyes and its mouth is located on the underside of its head.

name: Fangtooth
text: In proportion to their body size, fangtooths have the biggest recorded teeth in the ocean - they can't even fully close their mouth!

name: Feather Star
text: Although they look like moving plants, feather stars are crinoids and closely related to seastars.

name: Firefly Squid
text: These small bioluminescent creatures emit light to attract their prey, which makes them resemble fireflies - hence their name.

name: Flapjack Octopus
text: Not only you think this species of dumbo octopus is adorable: scientists called it "adorabilis" for its cute appearance.

name: Footballfish
text: This glowing anglerfish is covered in neuromasts, which allow it to detect the slightest movement in the dark water.

name: Frilled Shark
text: This deep-sea shark uses it senses to hunt along the seabed, lunging at prey and either using its over 200 pin-sharp teeth or even swallowing the prey whole.

name: Gelatinous Blindfish
text: Often called ghost fish because of its translucent skin and eerie, colorless eyes, this spooky fish has only been spotted alive once.

name: Supergiant Amphipod
text: Alicella gigantea is the largest species of amphipod ever observed. They are mostly detritivores or scavengers and are found even in the Challenger Deep, the deepest known point in the ocean.

name: Giant Isopod
text: This giant species of isopod can grow bigger than a guinea pig, even though it's related to the tiny pillbug.

name: Giant Oarfish
text: Oarfish are likely the source of  many sea serpent myths of the past as they rarely appear at the ocean surface.

name: Giant Ostracod
text: The ostracod's bodies are hinged like clams so they can disappear into their pods with only their antennas out.

name: Giant Pyrosome
text: The bioluminescent pyrosomes are colonial organisms that are made up of thousand of individuals, known as zooids. These indiviuals can reproduce via cloning, meaning every one is genetically identical.

name: Giant Siphonophore
text: Siphonophores are invertebraes, made up of specialized 'organ-like', but also autonomous parts und can grow larger than blue whales.

name: Giant Squid
text: The giant squid is origin of many myths - people once thought they were sea monks or mermen, mythical creatures that were part fish-like and part human.

name: Giant Tube Worm
text: These worms have no mouth or butt, so they rely on the bacteria living inside of their bodies for nutrition.

name: Glass Octopus
text: The rare, elusive glass octopus is nearly entirely transparent - only its eyes, optic nerve and digestive tract are opaque.

name: Goblin Shark
text: As one of the deep sea's most unique predators, the goblin shark swims rather slowly but can extend its jaw forwards in mere seconds to swallow unexpecting prey.

name: Gummy Squirrel
text: Scientists believe the gummy bear's long bright tail might be used as a sail to ride on deep ocean currents in order to move to better feeding grounds on the seafloor.

name: Hammerhead Shark
text: These shark's hammer-shaped heads are equipped with electrical receptors that can sense potential prey, even when it's hiding in the sand.

name: Hatchetfish
text: The hatchetfish uses rows of photophores on its belly to conceal its shadow and silhouette by matching the light around them. This strategy is also known as "bioluminescent counter-illumination".

name: Headless Chicken Monster
text: Unlike most sea cucumbers, this species is able to swim and it was named as a joke by scientists that saw its resemblance to a chicken.

name: Japanese Spider Crab
text: This giant crab's shell stays the same size after maturing while its leg continue growing.

name: Lion's Mane Jellyfish
text: Including it's long, flowing tentacles the lion's mane can grow over 30m long, which is longer than a blue whale.

name: Megamouth Shark
text: While it looks dangerous, this shark is the smallest of all 3 filter-feeding sharks and swims with its giant mouth constantly open to filter out its plankton prey.

name: Humboldt Squid
text: This squid likely lives for only a single year, but grows rapidly to reach its maximum size and reproduces multiple times before it dies.

name: Nautilus
text: The nautilus is a distant cousin to octopi and squids and according to fossil records, similar animals have existed for about 500 million years.

name: Octopoteuthis Squid
text: When fleeing from a predator isn't enough, this squid will purposefully lose one of its arms to confuse the enemy. It does however not amputate its entire arm, but only the part that has come in contact with the predator

name: Pacific Blackdragon
text: Black dragonfish are sexually dimorphic, a condition in which sexes of the same species exhibit different characteristics. Female dragonfish can grow about 40 cm long and are black with stripes, while the males can only get up to 5cm long and are brown, lacking the canine teeth and pelvic fins.

name: Pacific Hagfish
text: Hagfish are renowned for their ability to produce copious amounts of slime to escape predators by confusing them or clogging their mouth and gills.

name: Pelican Eel
text: Also known as gulper eel, this fish can create a massive net with its mouth to scoop up prey.

name: Phantom Jelly
text: This spectacular jellyfish was first discovered in 1899 and since then has only been seen 110 times, even though it is believed to be widespread around the globe and it can surpass 12m in length.

name: Pink-See Through Fantasia
text: This mobile sea cucumber feeds on sediment and uses bioluminescence to deter predators. Their sticky skin can also leave glowing "paint" on predator's skins which reveals their location.

name: Pointy Nosed Blue Chimaera
text: Also called ghost shark or ratfish, the mythical-looking chimaera has no bones in its body as it is related to sharks, rays and other cartilaginous fish.

name: Portuguese Dogfish
text: This shark is one of the deepest dwelling sharks, having been spotted down to 3.7km below the surface.

name: Portuguese Man o' War
text: This fascinating creature is not a jellyfish but a siphonophore, an animal made up of colony of organism that work together to form "organs", like tentacles and a digestive organ.

name: Psychedelic Jelly
text: This stunning species is one of the few jellyfish that bear their babies alive instead of releasing eggs and sperm into the water.

name: Sarcastic Fringehead
text: These colorful fish use their massive mouth to fight over their territory by smashing them together until one is able to bite the other.

name: Sea Angels
text: Sea angels have the remarkable ability to switch genders. Specifically, they are protandrous hermaphrodites, which means they start out male and turn female throughout the course of their lives.

name: Sea Lamprey
text: These jawless fish have been around longer than dinosaurs and trees. The young start as filter feeders and after  2-7 years they upgrade to a parasitic lifestyle, sucking on whales and fish.

name: Stareater
copyright: © Museum of Comparative Zoology, Harvard University
text: This mysterious deep sea fish is also called Snaggletooth and use a bioluminescent red barrel that sticks out of their chin to lure in prey, similar to other predators in the dark.

name: Terrible-claw Lobster
text: This lobster's claw is so scary that it got the crustacean named: Its name derives from the Greek roots "dinos" (terrible or fearful) and "chela" (claw).

name: Zombie Worm
text: Craving bones instead of brains, these tiny faceless worms survive by eating the bones of dead whales that fall to the bottom of the ocean.

name: Dana Octopus Squid
text: Like most deep-sea squids this species has light organs called photophores. What makes them special are their size, as these lemon-sized organs are by far the largest photophores known to science.

name: Red Knight
text: The Red Knight lives in the Antarctic deep sea and while its red color might appear vibrant to us, it renders the crustacean nearly invisible as red light waves do not penetrate its deep habitat.

name: Deep Sea Copeopd
text: This bioluminscent copepod's light is bright enough for its pigment to be used by molecular biologists as dye to visualize lab experiments.

name: Greenland Shark
text: Greenland sharks are the longest-living vertebrae known, having a lifespan of up to 400 years or more. Therefore they can take a lot of time to grow and reach 4 metres after approximately 150 years.

name: Bony-eared Assfish
text: As if the name weren't bad enough, this deep-sea species of cusk eel may have the smallest brain-to-body weight ratio of all vertebraes.

name: Big-eye Jellyhead
text: This delicate octoupus is rarely seen by humans, but when it is it seems to be putting on a show by expanding its long, billowing arms.

name: Venus Girdle
scientific: Although it is one of the biggest jellyfish in the ocean, little is known about this deep-dwelling red giant.
text: This graceful ribbon-like ctenophore is actually the largest known comb jelly. It swims horizontally by using muscular contractions as well as the beating of its comb rows.
